newsitem.title: HUNGARY: MOL, APV SAY MOL DOMESTIC OFFER TO SUCCEED.
newsitem.headline: MOL, APV SAY MOL DOMESTIC OFFER TO SUCCEED.

text.p: Hungarian privatisation agency APV Rt and MOL Rt officials said on Thursday they were confident the domestic issue of MOL shares will be successful.
"All signs point to a similar (subscriber) interest to the international private placement," APV General Director Pal Szabo told a news conference.

APV has offered 12.3 million shares or a 12.5 percent stake in MOL internationally, with a 2.5 percent over-allotment option, and a one percent stake with a three percent over-allotment option domestically.
The domestic subscription will start on May 12, at an issue price of 2,970 forints per share.
Szabo said that after the international roadshow from April 21 to May 2, the stake was more than six times or some $1.2 billion oversubscribed.
The proportion of U.S. investors was 41 percent, followed by the UK with 35 percent, Europe with 16 percent and the Middle and Far East with 8 percent, Szabo said.
"This shows that even traditionally conservative Japanese investors were prepared to venture into buying these shares," Szabo said.
MOL's General Director Zoltan Mandoki said the company wants to prove it can grow into a true multinational.
"We continue our expansion plans in the neighbouring countries... and we are also expanding our exploration and mining activity," Mandoki said.
He said MOL has not abandoned its plans to buy a 12.5 percent stake in the Adriatic pipeline but would only do so as a strategic investor with a proportional role in decision-making.
The Croatian privatisation agency HFP accepted in January MOL's offer of some 90 million German marks for a 12.5 percent stake in the pipeline operator Janaf but the deal is yet to be concluded.

Mandoki also said the company, which had made a loss on its gas sales for the last years, hopes that the government will fulfill its legal obligation of an eight percent return on equity for the energy sector.
Hungary promised investors in its privatised energy sector an eight percent return on investment.
The first energy prices adjusted to that effect were set in January and are revised quarterly by Hungary's Energy Office.
"Some of our costs, like the 22 billion forints invested in the Zsana gas storage facility, were not taken into account when prices were set," Mandoki said.
On the Budapest Stock Exchange, MOL shares closed at 3,460 forints, down 30.
